Award.AwardTitle: US-Singapore Workshop: Collaborative Research: Understand the World by Analyzing Many Video Streams
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF CNIC

US-Singapore Workshop: Collaborative Research: Understand the World by Analyzing Many Video Streams


Many thousands of network cameras provide near real-time view of the world. Valuable scientific information could be extracted by analyzing the large amounts of data. However, most of the data are never analyzed or archived. Analysis programs must be able to retrieve data from distributed sources, manage network accesses, schedule computation resources, allocate storage space, analyze the data, store the results, and present the results in formats that are easy to comprehend. Although the data are available, analyses today are limited due to the lack of a software framework to write and execute computer programs.


To harvest the knowledge from the data, the researchers from six universities are creating a system that can analyze the vast amount of visual data. The team will organize a workshop in December 2014 in Singapore. In this workshop, the team will share the information of the projects currently been conducted independently in the six universities. The researchers will present and demonstrate their projects, discuss and develop a plan for collaboration. The team includes Yung-Hsiang Lu (lead, Purdue University), Ketan Mayer-Patel (University of North Carolina), Cong Liu (University of Texas Dallas), Wei Tsang Ooi (National University of Singapore), Jason Gu (Singapore University of Technology and Design), Yonggang Wen (Nanyang Technological University).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop supported by this NSF award was held on December 16th and 17th, 2014 in the School of Computer Science of the National University of Singapore. More than 20 faculties and students (including those who are not supported by this award) participated in this workshop. There are 16 presentations in total given during the two-day workshop, including six presentations given by faculties and 10 student presentations. The faculty are Yung­Hsiang Lu (Purdue University), Cong Liu (University of Texas), Ketan Mayer­Patel (University of North Carolina), Roger Zimmermann and Wei Tsang Ooi (National University of Singapore), and Yonggang Wen (Nanyang Technological University). The students are Kyle McNulty, Everett Berry, Seth Bontrager, Ahmed Kaseb, and Youngsol Koh (Purdue), Yichao Jin, Weida Xu, Jianxiong Yin, and Xiao Liu (Nanyang Technological University), and Ying Zhang (National University of Singapore).

The presented and discussed topics include: 1) the design, implementation, and evluation of the CAM2 (continuous analysis fo many cameras) system, 2) the challenges on the networking side for managing large-schale many video streams, 3) real-time visual analytics, 4) effective and adaptive video compression and its applications, 5) utilizing public and private cloud resources to accelerate the processing of many camera streams. A wide rage of general topics related to video analytics, cloud computing, real-time analysis, networking have also been extensively discussed during the workshop.

The outcomes of this workshop include:

Two research papers published in IEEE Infocom 2016. These papers discussed issues related to developing techniques to reduce latency for supporting applications such as visual analytics in wireless networks or social networks. These two papers are entitled: "Taming Collisions for Delay Reduction in Low-Duty-Cycle Wireless Sensor Networks" and "Terminal-Set-Enhanced Community Detection in Social Networks". 

Ketan Mayer­Patel, Yung­Hsaing Lu, and Cong Liu submitted a proposal to NSF Visual and Experiential Computing (VEC) entitled "Large­Scale Visual Computing from World­Wide Data Streams". This proposal was declined.


Last Modified: 12/11/2015
Modified by: Cong Liu
